The SAFE Banking Act did pass in the House but it's important to notice that it was also proposed in the Senate under the same name 3 weeks after being introduced to the House. On April 11, 2019 it was referred to the Senate Banking Committee (the same committee where it now sits) where no action was taken. Now, after passing in the House, there are a number of steps that must be taken in order to become law before July: 1) The Senate Banking Committee doesn't just ignore it like it did last time 2) It must make it to the floor and the Senate must either (a) pass it using the exact same language as the House did OR (b) pass it with different language that is corrected by a review committee AND approved by the committee 3) Either (a) the president signs the bill OR (b) veto the bill FOLLOWED BY both the House and the Senate overruling the veto by a 2/3rds majority 4) This must happen before July 1
Congress moves slow

I’m for legalisation personally (Mostly decriminalised here), but if in US would you want to proceed with this info (per Economist): “ America is loosening the reins on marijuana use; it is now banned outright in just 17 states. But a new study published in JAMA Psychiatry , a journal, gives food for thought. Researchers compared “cannabis use disorder” in Washington, Colorado, Oregon and Alaska—the first states to legalise recreational marijuana use—against states in which recreational pot is still prohibited. CUD is medicalese for uncontrolled use. It is characterised by high tolerance levels, failed attempts to quit, or abdicating important activities to smoke. In adults over 26 years old, this rose by 37% more in states in which the drug is legal than elsewhere. Frequent use (at least 20 days of the preceding month) increased an extra 23%. Most troubling is the 25% greater uptick in CUD in children aged 12-17. An associated editorial warns that as more states consider legalisation, these health warnings must be weighed against the acknowledged “social-justice goals” of more liberal drug laws.”

This bill passed the House of Representatives pretty overwhelmingly. It seems to have support from both parties and is not a substantial change, it seems to mostly protect financial institutions. The real stumbling blocks I see are the time frame (9 months), McConnell, and Trump. The time frame at this point is sufficiently long that there is plenty of time to pass the bill (I think the average bill takes 7 months). Supposedly McConnell met with Marijuana Financiers about this bill recently, which gives me some confidence he will let it come to a vote, where it seems highly likely to pass. [1] Trump seems to have been pretty inconsistent on Marijuana, sometimes saying states should be allowed to legalize it and sometimes saying states should only allow medicinal marijuana. I don't think he would stop legislation if it passed, but if he put pressure to prevent it, I doubt Congress would stand up or override him.
I believe this is one of the VERY FEW things that will go through in the short term.
